column3: up after the fact. [SEP] But I do know that, in its original context, it was creationism that was being used. [SEP] And so, again, you're associating Young Earth creationism with intelligent design?

column1: First, a couple of follow-ups from the vice presidential debate last week. [SEP] Vice President Gore, would you support or sign, as president, a federal law banning racial profiling by police and other authorities at all levels of government? [SEP] Yes, I would. [SEP] The only thing an executive order can accomplish is to ban it in federal law enforcement agencies, but I would also support a law in the Congress that would have the effect of doing the same thing. [SEP] I just -- I think that racial profiling is a serious problem. I remember when the stories first
column3: out about the stops in New Jersey by the highway patrol there. And I know it's been going on a long time. In some ways this is just a new label for something that has been going on for years. But I have to confess that it was the first time that I really focused on it in a new way. And I was surprised at the extent of it. And I think we've now got so many examples around the country that we really have to find ways to end this. Imagine what it -- what it is like for someone to be singled out unfairly, unjustly, and feel the unfair force of law simply because of race or ethnicity. [SEP] Now, that runs counter to what the United States of America is all about at our core. [SEP] And it's not an easy problem to solve. [SEP] But if I am entrusted with the presidency, it will be the first Civil R

column1: -- let's talk about my tax plan. [SEP] The top 1% will pay one-third of all the federal income taxes. [SEP] And in return, get one-fifth of the benefits, because most of the tax reductions go to the people at the bottom end of the economic ladder. [SEP] That stands in stark contrast, by the way, to a man who is going to leave 50 million -- 50 million Americans out of tax relief. [SEP] We just have a different point of view. [SEP] It's a totally different point of view. [SEP] He believes only the right people ought to get tax relief. [SEP] I believe everybody who pays taxes ought to get tax relief. [SEP] Let me go back to Texas, for example, for a minute. [SEP] We pay 4.7 billion. [SEP] I can't emphasize to you how much. [SEP] I signed a bill that puts CHIPS in place. [SEP] The bill finally
column3: out at the end of the 1999 session. [SEP] We're working hard to sign up children. [SEP] We're doing it faster than any other state our size, comparable state. [SEP] We're making really good progress. [SEP] And our state cares a lot about our children. [SEP] My priority is going to be the health of our citizens. [SEP] These folks have had eight years to get something done in Washington, D.C. on the uninsured. [SEP] They have not done it. [SEP] They've had eight years to get something done on Medicare. [SEP] And they have not got it done. [SEP] And my case to the American people is, if you're happy with inactivity, stay with the horse. [SEP] The horse is up there now. [SEP] But if you want change, you need to get somebody that knows how to bring Republicans and Democrats together to get posit

column1: I think it's important to promote a culture of life. [SEP] I think a hospitable society is a society where every being counts and every person matters. [SEP] I believe the ideal world is one in which every child is protected in law and welcomed to life. [SEP] I understand there's great differences on this issue of abortion, but I believe reasonable people can come together and put good law in place that will help reduce the number of abortions. [SEP] Take, for example, the ban on partial birth abortion. [SEP] It's a brutal practice. [SEP] People from both political parties
column3: together in the halls of Congress and voted overwhelmingly to ban that practice. [SEP] It made a lot of sense. [SEP] My opponent, in that he's out of the mainstream, voted against that law. [SEP] What I'm saying is, is that as we promote life and promote a culture of life, surely there are ways we can work together to reduce the number of abortions: continue to promote adoption laws -- it's a great alternative to abortion -- continue to fund and promote maternity group homes; I will continue to promote abstinence programs.

column1: No record of leadership. [SEP] I
column3: to Washington to solve problems. [SEP] I was deeply concerned about seniors having to choose between prescription drugs and food. [SEP] And so I led. [SEP] And in 2006, our seniors will get a prescription drug coverage in Medicare. [SEP] Senator Kerry? [SEP] Thirty seconds.

column1: There is a problem for our youngsters, a real problem. [SEP] And if we don't act today, the problem will be valued in the trillions. [SEP] And so I think we need to think differently. [SEP] We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. [SEP] But for our children and our grandchildren, we need to have a different strategy. [SEP] And recognizing that, I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. [SEP] It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, a Democrat. [SEP] And they
column3: up with a variety of ideas for people to look at. [SEP] I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account, because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.

column1: But I'll never fail to protect the United States of America. [SEP] In 1990, there was a vast coalition put together to run Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. [SEP] The international community, the international world said this is the right thing to do, but when it

column1: I think we've got a lot more work to do. [SEP] And as president, I will always respect everybody's right to practice religion as they choose -- or not to practice -- because that's part of America. [SEP] Senator Kerry, after 9/11 -- and this is a new question for you -- it seemed to me that the country
column3: together as I've never seen it come together since World War II. [SEP] But some of that seems to have melted away. [SEP] I think it's fair to say we've become pretty polarized, perhaps because of the political season. [SEP] But if you were elected president, or whoever is elected president, will you set a priority in trying to bring the nation back together? [SEP] Or what would be your attitude on that?

column1: We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain, and I'm glad he did. column3: to this debate tonight that the three of us share something. [SEP] All three of us are surrounded by very strong women. [SEP] We're all married to strong women.
